Removal technique: Wet peroxide Oxidation subjected to density
Description: -Oxidation in the Presence of a Fe(II) catalyst to Digest labile organic matter.The plastic Debris remains Unaltered.  The mixture is Subjected to density separation in NaCl(aq) to Isolate the plastic debris through flotation.  -The floating Solids are Separated from the denser undigested Mineral components using a density separator.

Removal technique: peroxymonosulfate by sewage sludge  biochar-based catalyst
Description: a sludge-derived biochar (SBC) was prepared as an efficient and low-cost metal-free catalyst to activate PMS for the  abatement of bisphenol A (BPA) in water.

-Hydrothermally produced micron spheres of nano-rod-composed cobalt-doped LaFeO3 perovskites  (LaCo0.5Fe0.5O3) were used to activate peroxymonosulfate (PMS) for the degradation of bisphenol A.  -In search of low-cost alternatives to platinum group metal catalyst, perovskite-type oxides  (LaMeO3, Me = transition metal Fe, Co, Mn, Ni) have gained a lot of interest. LaFeO3 is a common perovskite that  benefits from the category's standard attributes, including ease of synthesis, low cost, and lack of toxicity.
Adsorption and biodegradation are two dominant removal mechanisms in BPs in this process.

--solar activated catalysts and composite materials capable of enhancing adsorption and degradation.   -ROS(reactive oxygen species) utilised for the degradation of PAEs.  --TiO2 doped materials such as Fe, Ag co-doped ZnO can be used as a photo-active material across several platforms  and that it is cheap, non-toxic, and chemically inert is what led to the majority of the earliest work in  photocatalytic applications.

-The standard reactors lose energy because of the excessive ozone waste. Since quick oxidation of organic  compounds and reduced ozone loss are both necessary for effective ozone-based wastewater treatment,  microbubble technology has been applied to enhance gas-liquid contactors for this purpose.  The gas-liquid interface is electrically charged, the rising velocity through water is low,  the surface is highly curved, and the interfacial area is huge.

Removal technique: Catalytic reduction using sodium borohydride  with nano-catalysts
Description: -During catalytic reduction, CR molecules are cleaved at the azo link, resulting in byproducts that are safer for humans  and the environment. Reduction is favoured over other techniques including coagulation/flocculation, ozonation,  and photocatalytic degradation because the reduction products of CR are useful in many different contexts.  -CR molecules to reduce them into aromatic amines and  H2

Removal technique: Carboxyl-Functionalized Covalent Organic  Frameworks for the Adsorption
Description: -carboxyl-COF shows good crystallinity, mesoporous pores, and high chemical stability.   It was applied for ultrafast adsorption and the efficient elimination of triphenylmethane dyes.   -The ultrafast kinetics, high adsorption capacity, and good reusability endow the carboxyl-functionalized COF  with great potential for removing triphenylmethane dyes from an aqueous environment.

-Photocatalysis is a technology that uses visible light to break down different kinds of organic pollutants  into harmless CO2, water, and other inorganic substances.  -The large band gap of 3.2 eV-3.5 eV in BiOCl photocatalyst allows it to absorb UV light.

Removal technique: Removal of organic pollutants  in water using water hyacinth
Description: -Water hyacinth can absorb organic compounds from the contaminated water which is an interesting benefit of this  invasive species in water.   -Both organic and inorganic contaminants can be effectively removed using water hyacinth as an adsorbent.     -High porosity, low skeletal density, outstanding magnetism, hydrophobic capabilities, and lipophilic ability  marked the resulting adsorbent, which proved to be an excellent material for oil adsorption after Fe3O4  magnetic particles were added to boost its magnetic and mechanical strength.

Sand filtration is used for the removal of suspended matter, as well as floating and sinkable particles.  The wastewater flows vertically through a fine bed of sand and/or gravel. Particles are removed by way of  absorption or physical encapsulation.
